interlinear-text.item: ELA The Meaning of my Lullaby

phrase.item: A lullaby is usually sung by a mother to her child or grandchild.
She takes the child from the cradle and shakes him,
but it's when she puts the child to sleep that she would sing the lullaby to make the child calm down and sleep well.
The lullaby helps the child fall asleep.
A mother would sing lullaby and keep shaking the cradle and the child would fall asleep.

Our mother used to sing us lullabies and it was passed on to us, so we also sing lullabies to our children. And we sing to our grandchildren to put them to sleep. Without hearing lullabies, they almost can't sleep.
When they keep hearing the singing of lullabies and the cradle is rocking, that's the way they fall asleep When a child starts learning the language,
the lullabies are usually sung in the Wakhi language,
the language which was passed down to us, so we also try to teach our children the language through lullabies.
When we transmit our love and care through singing, [lullabies], the child senses it on a deep level. That sense of love and care they carry with them into adulthood.
It stays in their mind that lullabies are sung with love, and it's a culture. Even when they grow up they still remember that lullabies were sung to them.
Among us Wakhis, singing lullabies is a custom and everyone can sing.
Even our little children would sing lullabies [as a form of play].
Lullabies have been always there and never disappeared.

Just now when I sang a lullaby, I felt as if my mother was singing it to me. I recalled and felt all her love toward me. Saying that, I want to pass all that love and care to my own child. I sing it to my child, and pass on the love that my mother passed to me — I pass it to my child [or children].
It will continue when my child grows up tomorrow [in the future], and she will be aware of lullabies. She will sing them as well.
Lullabies can be sung to a son or daughter, it doesn't matter.
The same lullaby can be sung to a son or daughter
If the [mother] has a son in the cradle, she would mention his name. if a daughter, then she mentions her name.
Lullabies are all the same to everyone, there is no [gender] difference,
children are all the same [to a mother].
At the beginning, when a child is just born, their brain is clear.
When the mother puts the child to bed and sings lullabies, and says sweet words, the child picks up words and learns the language, the Wakhi language,
and it stays in their mind.
Through lullabies, the child learns quickly,
In addition, the sense of love and care stays in their mind too. Lullabies have been sung for generations and never go away
Through lullabies, a mother bonds [with her child], developing a strong relationship and the love is extended.
The child also can feel his mother's presence, as she gets closer and sings lullabies that can make him sleep easily.
The sound of a lullaby makes the child feel good.
The love which was passed down to us through lullabies has stayed in us till today.
In that same way we sing to our children.
An when they grow up, they will sing to their children.
So that way the tradition continues,
and our language won't disappear as well.
Singing lullabies will also be kept as a tradition.
